stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes the Course 15 boss: a corrupted “Pentapus” Yoshi whose tentacles emerge from blue-hole portals.  He scripts tentacle behavior, collision, lighting and camera shake while discussing overall game progress, boss counts, side-level scope, porting issues and team workloads.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 boss will be a mutated “Yoshi Pentapus” with five tentacles; players jump on a tentacle, break glowing tumors (wards), then attack nose tumors when the head drops; repeat three times.  Later phases add simultaneous tentacles, faster speed and baby-projectile attacks.
development_findings.quote: You jump on the tentacle and destroy the ward; Yoshi gets weak, his nose is exposed, you punch the ward and that’s damage—repeat three times.

development_findings.summary: Tentacles use spline hitboxes; Kaze toggles solidity and damage frames, scales animation speed after hits and adds camera shake at impact.
Blue-hole portals spawn tentacles.  A cheap N64 shader plus a broad light cone warns players where a strike will emerge.
development_findings.quote: We need this light to exist so you can tell what’s going on before it hits Mario.

development_findings.summary: Akumoid and Kaze built a new reflection shader that adds free environmental reflections to buildings and will later be applied to rockets.
development_findings.quote: Together we came up with this one… it looks so cool and it’s literally free.

development_findings.summary: RTYI now plans nine side levels (originally six) and nine main-course boss fights.
development_findings.quote: Nowadays there’s a good chance that it’s actually going to be like nine side levels.

development_findings.summary: Course 13 is waiting on an outside area Zeina is modeling; Course 14 gameplay done but visuals await violet; Course 15 boss in active development.
development_findings.quote: Thirteen is missing the outside area—Zeina’s been working on it for a long time now—and Course 14 is done but a lot of the visuals are left for violet.

development_findings.summary: Kaze will hide encrypted messages inside the Pentapus’s text boxes using multiple undisclosed cipher techniques.
development_findings.quote: I’m thinking of some cryptographic messages we send the player… we need a few more encryption techniques.

development_findings.summary: He is considering YSK static recompilation to ship RTYI on multiple platforms without emulators.
development_findings.quote: I might legitimately just use YSK static recompilation to properly import the game to everything at once.

development_findings.summary: Rideable Yoshi mechanics are easy to re-add; some green-star missions will likely feature them.
development_findings.quote: Implementing a playable Yoshi is very easy—I’ve done it before.

context_findings.summary: Kaze deliberately avoids revealing political positions to preserve broad appeal (‘halo effect’) and steers clear of cancel-worthy chat topics.
context_findings.quote: If people like you they assume other good things… better to not make controversial political statements.

context_findings.summary: He shows frustration with repetitive ‘How are you?’ questions but stays polite, revealing streaming fatigue.
context_findings.quote: It’s my least favorite question—people being polite but also pissing me off so I can’t react impolitely.

context_findings.summary: He values gameplay readability over strict realism, e.g., exaggerating portal light so players can dodge attacks.
context_findings.quote: The light doesn’t make 100 % physical sense, but we need it to exist.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s open-source stance: fans may port hacks if they do it alone; he refuses to support half-finished or inaccurate ports.
context_findings.quote: If you can do it yourself without my help, you can do whatever you want, but as soon as you start asking me for help I’m annoyed.

biobak.summary: Will remake the Pentapus model once Kaze finishes the placeholder, using it as reference.
biobak.quote: They’re more like a symbolic representation so that when Biobak remakes my model, he knows what I was going for.

badub.summary: Composes music; track played on stream, leading Kaze to joke about Badub being ‘royalty’.
badub.quote: I guess Badub is royalty now—he’s famous.

zeina.summary: Tasked with Course 13 outside area; progress has been slow but ongoing for a long time.
zeina.quote: Thirteen is missing the outside area—Zeina wanted to work on that; she’s been working on it for a long time now.

key_stories.title: Testing a Co-op Deluxe PC Port
key_stories.summary: Viewers claim a quality PC-co-op port of Peach’s Fury exists. Kaze inspects footage live, first spotting a broken early build, then a better version, yet still riddled with missing features and wrong collisions.
key_stories.challenge: Verify community claim that a faithful port is playable.
key_stories.process: Watches shared videos, checks for missing water, backgrounds, trampolines, carousel, and movement accuracy.
key_stories.outcome: Concludes port is ‘very rough around the edges’; reiterates policy of no support for external ports.
key_stories.key_quote: I can clearly see some parts are pretty rough… I doubt they would even get close to getting Return to Yoshi’s Island right.

key_stories.title: Building a Cheap Reflection Shader
key_stories.summary: Akumoid contacts Kaze to learn N64 shaders. Together they craft a reflection mask that adds glossy highlights to metallic buildings at virtually zero performance cost.
key_stories.challenge: Achieve next-gen reflection look within N64 constraints.
key_stories.process: Iterative DM collaboration, experimentation, implementation into current build.
key_stories.outcome: Shader works; plan to apply it to space rocket asset next.
key_stories.key_quote: You’d think this is expensive, but this is literally free—just developer time.
